citations.narrative:
The walk-through aviary containing pelicans, wood storks, Ibises, night herons and various species of ducks contains
numerous holes in the rigid wire mesh surrounding the aviary. There are areas at the top of the enclosure where at least
four large openings are present in the wire mesh that need repair. A facility representative stated that wild crows had
chewed and broken the wires, creating these holes to enter the enclosure. Openings in the wire mesh of the enclosure
may result in bird escapes, injuries or death. The facility must ensure bird enclosures are maintained in good repair,
protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the
welfare of the birds within. Correct by November 20, 2024.

At the time of inspection, most of the outdoor bird enclosures lack appropriate shelter from wind and/or precipitation. Each
affected enclosure has a roofed area that lacks adequate sides to provide an effective windbreak.
** The enclosure housing four blue and gold macaws, a hyacinth macaw, and an umbrella cockatoo lacks adequate
shelter from wind and precipitation.
** The enclosure housing two black vultures and two turkey vultures has roofed areas but lacks adequate shelter from
wind and precipitation.
** One enclosure housing a bald eagle and another housing a black vulture did not provide any opportunities to inhibit
wind entering the exhibit.
** The enclosure housing an umbrella cockatoo has a roof but lacks adequate shelter from wind and precipitation.
** The enclosure that houses two military macaws, a ruby macaw, and a Major Mitchell’s cockatoo lacks adequate shelter
from wind and precipitation.
** The enclosure housing two keel-billed toucans lacks adequate shelter from wind and precipitation.
Inadequate shelter from wind and precipitation may result in illness, discomfort, or distress to the birds, and may have a
negative impact on their physical condition and well-being. All outdoor housing facilities for birds must provide enough
shelter that is large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct
sunlight, precipitation, or wind. Correct by January 23,2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have an environmental enhancement plan for birds. This plan is necessary to ensure the
psychological well-being and health of the animals. The facility must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate
plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be
approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan must be made
available to APHIS upon request. Correct by November 20,2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The walk-through aviary containing pelicans, wood storks, Ibises, night herons and various species of ducks contains 
numerous holes in the rigid wire mesh surrounding the aviary. There are areas at the top of the enclosure where at least 
four large openings are present in the wire mesh that need repair. A facility representative stated that wild crows had 
chewed and broken the wires, creating these holes to enter the enclosure. Openings in the wire mesh of the enclosure 
may result in bird escapes, injuries or death. The facility must ensure bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, 
protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the 
welfare of the birds within. Correct by November 20, 2024. 
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
At the time of inspection, most of the outdoor bird enclosures lack appropriate shelter from wind and/or precipitation. Each 
affected enclosure has a roofed area that lacks adequate sides to provide an effective windbreak.  
 
** The enclosure housing four blue and gold macaws, a hyacinth macaw, and an umbrella cockatoo lacks adequate 
shelter from wind and precipitation. 
 ** The enclosure housing two black vultures and two turkey vultures has roofed areas but lacks adequate shelter from 
wind and precipitation.  
** One enclosure housing a bald eagle and another housing a black vulture did not provide any opportunities to inhibit 
wind entering the exhibit.  
** The enclosure housing an umbrella cockatoo has a roof but lacks adequate shelter from wind and precipitation.  
** The enclosure that houses two military macaws, a ruby macaw, and a Major Mitchell’s cockatoo lacks adequate shelter 
from wind and precipitation.  
** The enclosure housing two keel-billed toucans lacks adequate shelter from wind and precipitation.  
 
Inadequate shelter from wind and precipitation may result in illness, discomfort, or distress to the birds, and may have a 
negative impact on their physical condition and well-being. All outdoor housing facilities for birds must provide enough 
shelter that is large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct 
sunlight, precipitation, or wind. Correct by January 23,2025.

3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not have an environmental enhancement plan for birds. This plan is necessary to ensure the 
psychological well-being and health of the animals. The facility must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate 
plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be 
approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations and with currently accepted 
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan must be made 
available to APHIS upon request. Correct by November 20,2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
